Posts.Content: Gosh I feel for you both as I remember the weeks of making the decisions prior to the operation. There are so many different experiences its is difficult - remember what I tell you now is just mine. To cut a long story short after diagnosis I was recommended a DEIP flap - its like a TRAM but instead of taking the muscle it  takes the fat from the abdomen for the reconstruction - the hospital I am at do not offer the TRAM very often and prefer the DEIP as they say there is less chance of Hernia in the future. I was amazed as I did not realise that this could be done. I was not recommended the second option (from the back) as I have full size breasts and was told this is only really for smaller ladies plus I would require an implant. I did not like the idea of an implant if I am honest - that is just me as - I have read comments on here from ladies who have had an implant and are doing well with it. I was told I would not require Chemo or Radio unless it was found in my lymph nodes and they doubted this would be the case. After the op I was told the cells were in the ducts but more widespread and near the surface of the skin but not in the lymph nodes. Because the cells were near the surface and high grade I was strongly recommended to have radiotherapy - I am about to complete 5 weeks of this. I questioned the effect R/T would have on my reconstruction and was told that it may affect the texture and size a little but not too much - this I will not know for a while until all the redness and swelling has gone from the R/T treatment. My cancer was not found as a lump - there were no symptons - it was found on Xray. It is called DCIS which is found in the milk ducts - so it is not classed as invasive type when caught early. I had extensive biopsies which indicated there was no spread out of the ducts so they said it was very doubful I would need chemo.You're situtation sounds different as chemo is being dicussed as a possible - I was told I would not have been able to have the reconctruction at the same time if I would have required chemo. Again I have spoken to some ladies and read comments on here that confirm that some had to wait for the reconstruction as they required cheme and R/T. Its not an easy time as there is so much to take in - have you looked at the information on this site regarding the procedures - plus I am sure you will soon find you have more mssages with more advice which will help you. Maybe you need to go back to your consultant now and discuss this again - it does take a while to sink in and I found the 2nd and 3rd time I was more informed and we had a better discussion. I think hospitals differ as well in what they offer - thats the impression I get anyway Thinking of you Barbara x

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon I am new to your conversation and a bit late suppporting you but just want to say  WELL DONE YOU for making your decision! Aren't we lucky to have all these great people helping us on this website. I had a Mastectomy in July this year after calcification found that was 8cm spread and high grade cells. I was told the chance of it spreading was high and a lumpectomy was out of the question. I was as scared as you and it took me 3 weeks to agree to the op. I also agreed to a reconstruction at the same time so my recovery has been longer due to the op on my tummy. I have spoken to a few ladies who faced the same as me - some having reconstruction a year later and no one was anything but scared. But the treatment we have in this country for this is amazing (this has already been said to you) and although everyone of us is individual and have different experiences- there are so many of us who have survived the op and recovery period. I was shaking the morning before my op - buut the staff are used to it and cope brillantly. I met someone who had the lump removed and then had to go back for another op soon after as they found the margin for the calcification was not clear so she ended up with the Mastecomy after all. I am half way through radio therapy (which |i did not think I would need) but luckily don't need chemo as my lymph nodes were clear. Good luck and think positive Barbara x

Posts.Content: Hi Muriel I had a Mastectomy (left side) and DEIP reconstruction in July 2010. I was in hospital for 10 days (this is more than normal as I had a mild skin infection in a few sutures but nothing serious). I was out of bed in 48 hours - only to go to the loo and sit in a chair (not for very long) but I managed it. Thank goodness for painkillers - they do get you through the first few weeks. My tummy was tender  to say the least and my reconstructed breast swollen for longer than they said it would be - but it was not a concern to them. Its a big op so I was warned I would be exhausted after and I was - eating was such a major effort! The first week is very tiring especially as you are checked so often - but all the nursing staff were fantastic and helped me through. the great thing is you look down and still have a breast - its amazing really. The drains were a bit strange but I just accepted they had a job to do for while and I had no choice. I was really scared when I went in for the op - but I got through! Having this method does mean a longer recovery time and your tummy will restrict you for a while. I had to take things slowly and soon learnt this really is an investment of time. August was spent at home sleeping  - night and day - propped up most of the time too! September was better I could stand up straighter and the tenderness was reducing really well. The tummy takes longer than the breast - even now I still have to be careful I dont over do it. I have healed well and have just about got used to my abdominal scar - its almost part of me now and I also have a lovely flat tummy! I have had to have Radio Therapy in the end (it was not orginally planned) this I am just coming to the end - without this I would have been back at work sooner. I don't want to paint too rosy a picture - its been a hard few months - but I came through and I have spoken to others who have too. I also dont have to go back for another major op - it seemed to make sense to me. My reconstruction has remained a little larger than my breast was originally so when I go for nipple reconstruction next year the plastic surgeon is going to reduce it with Lipo suction so I will be balanced, this will just be day surgery. I suppose the hardest part is that you just dont realise how long it will take for everything to settle ( well I certainly didnt't). I could only wear jeans/waistbands this week because I could not stand them pressing into my tummy - even my loose ones. So I have lived in leggins, jogging bottoms, long t shirts and jumpers - thank goodness they are in the shops! You can't wear a bra for a while after and then it has to be without underwires but there are quite a few sites on the net you can purchase from. If you have any questions I will try my best to answer them for you and I am sure there will lots more ladies sending you messages on here soon. Take care Barbara x
